The treatise says:
The consciousness arises from its own seeds because the nature of the cause is the same, and it is not obstructed.
The basis and objects of the five consciousnesses are the characteristics of the consciousness of the objects, just like mental consciousness.

Or, it is not separate from the nature of the mind and mental factors, because those eye consciousnesses and so forth have the same function of producing the cause, just like the dharma realm in the mind.
This explains the meaning of the sÅ«tra, which only speaks of the mind and does not establish a thesis.
What they refute also does not establish this slightly different meaning.
If this meaning is established, one should not speak of extensively creating various treatises again.
How can this be known?
It is just like the meaning of the intention to establish the result and the realm, and entering the non-nature of persons, speaking of the twelve sense bases is also like this.
If one departs from the self-nature of form and the eye, one can then enter into the nature of the non-existence of a person.
Why is this so?
This arises from the internal and external distinctions of the two sixes, namely, the eye and so forth, and the six objects such as form, and so forth.

It also does not arise from the distinctions of the seer and so forth, up to the function of the eye such as the eye contact and so forth. Apart from this self-nature, there should not be any other agent.
If one relies on the eye and so forth to perform activities, and freely enjoys them, this is said to be the self bound by the grasping of self.
In this case, it is only the internal and external bases that freely combine, and the functions of the eye and so forth arise and cease.
This is also not the self, because the eye and so forth are not in contact with it.
It is always inseparable from sentient beings, and is only said to be the cause.

However, the agent in the eye and so forth is also as explained before. Therefore, it does not arise from a separate category. By this, one can understand the principle of the non-existence of the nature of a person.
If a person is able to subdue without self-nature, then one who seeks tranquility can also enter this.
Why is this?

Because in birth and death one sees the oppression of various sufferings, and because of the impermanence of suffering, one's mind gives rise to disgust in birth and death, and the power of the view of no-self can suddenly abandon [birth and death].
One who fears the cessation of self gradually causes the causes to be exhausted, just as when firewood is exhausted the fire is extinguished.
Therefore the Buddha said:
For these kinds of people, he spoke of the twelve sense bases.
Some say that within this, he did not speak of the twelve sense bases for those without the principle of self-nature.
These two characteristics are equally without distinction, because of the existence of self-nature. The view of self is inverted, and because of the antidote, this is said to be reasonable.
Just as with the inversion of the antidote to inversion, this is not accepted and is also not well understood.
How can the distinctions of these sense bases and so forth that I establish be nonexistent?
The essence and characteristics of the mind and mental factors are distinct.
When this aspiration and mind and mental factors occur, the eye faculty is not the ear faculty, etc., because this is said to be the difference in characteristics.
It is the same here. At the same time, not one consciousness arises in them, which is the self-nature aspiration of the eye faculties, etc.
However, when form, etc. abides in the nature of gold, it is not the nature of silver, etc., and the characteristics are undifferentiated.
This gold, etc., apart from form, etc., cannot be said to have a separate substance.
This principle is the same here. Without differentiation, form, etc. are said to exist in substance.
If, as stated, due to the inversion of characteristics, it cannot be a remedy, this is the same as the previous attachment to the nature of sentient beings.
Just as those sentient beings, in the absence of self, see self, this is the nature of inversion, and this view is inverted.
This is able to eliminate, just as form, etc., eliminate the inversion of self, therefore.
If the continuity of mind is uninterrupted and without inversion, this is also unreasonable.
The similarity of the intrinsic nature and desire for non-erroneousness in this case is also not well understood due to the sequence.
If someone says:
The skillful entry into the selflessness of persons is explained, and the existence of the intrinsic nature of form and so forth is explained, just like the mental realm and the dharma realm.
If one delights in the intrinsic nature of mind and mental factors as the self, then there will be no dispute.
If there is a self apart from mind and mental factors, there is no analogy at all.
This discourse is like the general class of distinctions, not the ultimate truth.
If it is said that the skillful approach to the selflessness of intrinsic nature is also not so.
One should observe and establish this skillful approach, explaining form and so forth.
However, the Buddha's teachings only have such tasks to be done, namely, wanting to make one enter the selflessness of intrinsic nature. Why bother to further explain that there is only mind?
Since this does not exist, how can it be said that the explanation of the twelve sense bases is the underlying intent?

This is also unreasonable, because it further explains that dharmas are without self-nature, which is a very serious matter. Wishing to cause understanding and entry, the World-Honored One then says that form and so forth are dharmas without self-nature. Wishing to cause the other great bodhisattvas to attain that TathÄgata's supreme and wondrous position, to benefit the world of beings in all its vastness.
How is this done?
It is said that form and so forth are similar to what appears before us, but are only mind.
Apart from consciousness, there is never a single thing that can be seen as having the nature of form and so forth.
Therefore, we know that form and so forth are dharmas without self-nature.
This statement reveals that the self-nature of things is produced by the power of one's own consciousness transforming and manifesting, and the principle is certainly established.
According to what is known, all things are completely apart from consciousness and cannot be grasped separately. They are only this [consciousness] appearing in various forms.
Therefore, we know that there is truly no self-nature, and one is then able to understand and enter the principle of the naturelessness of dharmas.
Some say: If it is said that in order to awaken to the naturelessness of dharmas, this is said based on the ability to do so,

then the seen objects are only mistaken, based on the principle of ultimate truth, essentially empty and non-existent. Making this proclamation well accords with the Middle Way, because the seen objects are non-existent and consciousness is not existent.
This is certainly not yet familiar with what meaning is intended.

Moreover, it is said that the seen objects of such mind and mental factors do not correspond to the facts, falsely grasping unreal characteristics is called mistaken. How could it not be said that there is only consciousness?
If it is said that even oneness does not exist, then how can there be any proclamation?
Since objects are non-existent, and consciousness is not existent, using the analogy of dreams and so forth is good for understanding. As explained above, there is no need to be confused.
How is it that external objects are not obtained, but only consciousness appears?
The meaning of consciousness is unreasonable.
If it means having meaning, it is because it directly benefits the effect in terms of karma. This statement itself becomes the answer to the objection.
It also does not mean that it can accomplish distinction by having a separate substance.
Some say it means to uphold one's own substance, and this is the meaning of self-nature.
This is also the same as what has already been analyzed above.
This meaning is not correct. Apart from the instrument of action, there must be a separate matter in order to function, just as one's own self still upholds one's own body, so it is not appropriate.
In order to cause the understanding of the non-existence of dharmas, it is said that there is only consciousness, which is considered to be correct.

If it is said that in general all dharmas are without self, and for this reason it is called the selflessness of dharmas, then this is generally accepted that the self-nature of self is all non-existent. In this way, it becomes the selflessness of dharmas, and all dharmas do not exist.
For this reason, one should know that consciousness is also the same.
Since its nature does not exist, how can one establish it here?
If those dharmas are all non-existent, they are like a hypothetical self that continues in a series.
The absence of self-nature is what is accepted, that the nature of continuation in a series is completely non-existent.
This then becomes the non-existence of dharmas, meaning that all dharmas are without nature.
Therefore, one should know that consciousness is also the same.
Since this does not exist, how can one rely on this to cause deluded people to enter the non-existence of dharmas?
Due to the non-existence of a self, one is caused to realize the non-existence of dharmas.
This is universally accepted as a skillful means.
Then how does one wish to establish it?

The skillful means of establishing that the twelve sense bases prove the non-existence of a person is not actually the complete non-existence of all dharmas, which is then called the absence of self-nature of dharmas.

Therefore, one should know that the sound of the absence of self-nature of dharmas does not refer to the complete absence of self-nature of all dharmas. The word continuation in a series is also the same as this, not wishing to refer to the complete non-existence of everything.
However, the intended meaning is that the dharmas that arise from conditions are devoid of self-nature, and they are precisely the existence of this self-naturelessness.
What are their characteristics?
It means calling the self natureless, therefore it is called the self-naturelessness of persons, not that all dharmas are completely devoid of self-nature.
The dharmas such as form, etc., according to one aspect, are said to be natureless, not that they are completely nonexistent.
Therefore, one should know that the statement that dharmas are natureless does not mean that they are completely devoid of substance.
If it is said that all dharmas are completely nonexistent, then one should not say that dharmas are natureless, but rather that dharmas are completely nonexistent.
In that case, it is only due to the naturelessness of the grasped dharmas that there is the ability to attain distinctions.

Separating from the self-nature of others, distinguishing the substance of that real self, which is always nonexistent, this is the meaning of the self-naturelessness of dharmas, not that it is completely empty.
But what is the word grasped?

Namely, the inverted views and deluded attachments of ignorance, which mature from one's own mind's seeds, arise due to others and manifest different appearances, grasping at external objects as having a separate self-nature.
Just as inverted views give rise to understanding of external characteristics, when one gives rise to definite attachment to one's own views, this is then called the grasped object.
What is this again? It is said to be nothing.
How can nothing be called the grasped object?
It is for this reason.
If one grasps at this as having even a bit of real substance, it should not be called a conceptual object.
However, because of the correspondence in meaning, due to the mutual exclusion of the grasped real thing and its own nature, if there is a real thing, it is not called a conceptual object.
Within this scope of the proximate seen realm, all of this is said to be the grasped object.
Even if one uses consciousness as this object and makes it the object of measurement, it still becomes the meaning of the grasped object.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:

Therefore, you should know that the grasped consciousness is also natureless, which is the nature of consciousness only. This is the subtle method for realizing that all dharmas are without self-nature. It is only the root consciousness manifesting as various phenomena according to conditions, but there is no external object that can be obtained. From form to consciousness, all are like this. It is not that the consciousness that manifests the image part is also non-existent.

If it is said that this is different, and only the negation of form is spoken of as this consciousness only, then the words consciousness only will not be established, because the consciousness that takes consciousness as its object has an object.
Moreover, it will again be established that the consciousness that takes form as its object has an object.
What is its essence?
Apart from that, it cannot be spoken of. Only the Buddhas, the World-Honored Ones, are able to understand it.
How do they understand this meaning?
Later I will explain it.

This is precisely the true existence of the mind and mental factors that transcends the path of verbal expression and has a nature. It is also not reasonable to establish that all dharmas are completely nonexistent, the same as empty space.
Therefore, one should know that realizing true reality and skillfully entering the expedient teachings of consciousness only are in accord with principle.
By this sequence, one is gradually able to break through the net of discrimination and have the correct conditions.

If one allows the establishment of a place that transcends verbal expression as a truly existent thing, then this would still establish that form and so forth also share the same true nature, just like consciousness.
If so, then one should still ask where such a principle can be found.

Seeing that others allow for a consciousness that is not expressed, one would also cause form and so forth to be eliminated in the same way. This has never been seen to be the case. Because by liking honey and curd, one also desires them.
If you further speculate that it has this inseparable nature, the matter is the same as a sprout, which can have the causal function of producing a subsequent effect.
If you say it has an inseparable nature, please show the boundaries, and reason will definitely not find common agreement.
If you say that when consciousness is about to take something as an object, the grasped substance is called the grasped,

the real substance's appearance serves as the cause for its arising. Form is also like this, so it should also have the matter of being dependent on arising, and serve as a causal condition like consciousness. This would then become completely unlovable, because in the five aggregates, all are dependent on others and are accepted.
The meaning of the nature of dharmas that are imagined can be due to this principle being the same as that, because there is such a correct teaching statement.
If you say that form also has separation from consciousness, and is really dependent on others, just like feeling and so forth,
this intention has the fault of indefiniteness, because the grasped part also has consciousness.
The portion of feeling, etc., that arises from conditions is precisely the essence of the four aggregates.
However, the portion that manifests as images is established based on the aggregate of mind and mental factors.
Due to this principle, the analogy is certainly established, but there is no meaning of combination in the thesis, and there is also the fault of establishing what is already established.

The form that arises from conditions is also the intrinsic nature of feeling, etc., and therefore it is hoped that the fault can be removed by making a distinction in the cause and saying that it is because the distinguished arising of the grasped images manifests in consciousness.
This removes the fault of indeterminacy, but it is still within the images, and it is generally accepted.
The intrinsic nature of feeling, etc., is the nature of self-realization, because there is no object.
Since there is this principle, it can indeed be relied upon.
However, form has a separate existence, and there is no separate reason. Examining it through reasoning, it is certainly not the same.
If this is so, and all consciousnesses have no objects of cognition, how is this known?
Also, it is said, if there is another consciousness that can be the object of another consciousness?

It is also said that the realm of all Buddhas is a real dharma, and the objects of other consciousnesses. If one does not take the Buddha's realm as one's own mind as an object, then it is not possible to have any explanation.
Those who speak like this all set up falsehoods, because they think and speak in terms of symbols.

The characteristics that are expressed by words and meanings are precisely the many kinds of appearances manifested by consciousness alone. Although there are no external objects, it seems as if they touch the matter and consciousness can arise. This is the cause of the debate.
It is said that the sound that arises and then ceases, even if the sound of the teacher of the cessation teaching ceases, one should listen to its echo.
It is certainly not that there is anything to be attained in that, but rather one can discuss it together.

We can only allow that karma can create and that feeling is the experience of that. If you then claim that there must be a real self, how can you claim that there is a real self that can be perceived at that time?
Those who do not allow that two consciousnesses can be produced simultaneously claim that the substance of the other consciousnesses is destroyed immediately after they arise.
This kind of criticism is also not appropriate, because the other consciousnesses are not appropriate to experience this.
This statement also serves to refute the following objection.
As they say,
If it is known that an object exists, how do you know this?
This is also a case of conceptualization of a common characteristic in an object and is called knowledge. It also invites the same kind of criticism.ğŸ”½As they say,
The expression of the TathÄgata having superior qualities also implies that you must realize superior qualities.
Therefore, this is not the object of the Buddha.

It is also not the same as eating rice. This common characteristic is a real existent thing. Therefore, it is definitely known that one is able to understand it not by the power of external objects appearing before one, but only by the mind's imagination giving rise to it.
Since there is this principle, is it not difficult to understand the Buddha's realm? This then gives rise to discussion based on the treatise.
The ancillary meaning is now complete, but the secret meaning and its cause should be explained.
This secret meaning has two causes: first, contradicting other teachings; second, harming correct principles.
Teaching the doctrine of consciousness only is precisely the contradiction, because this Ägama does not say it is established.
Moreover, in that MÄyÄjÄla SÅ«tra, the Buddha spoke thus to those who give rise to discrimination regarding forms and other sense objects:

The forms cognized by this eye consciousness are not seen to truly exist or to definitely abide, but only give rise to false discrimination in deluded feelings, make definitive understanding, and give rise to discourse.
Only this is true, the other meanings are not established.
Thus extensively expounded, up to the gradual explanation of the Dharma, it is said:
The well-versed noble disciple should study like this.

I observe the past, future, and present, the eye consciousness observing all forms there, yet there is no constant, fixed, non-deluded, non-different real thing to be obtained, either as it is or with an undistorted nature, all of which do not exist.
Only the noble ones who transcend the world accomplish this truth.
The World-Honored One said this is all false, etc., contradicting the Ä€gamas and contradicting correct principles?
You should explain it first, then raise questions and give rise to doubts.
How do you know that what is said like this is not real?
It is just like saying consciousness, which is the meaning as stated.

Speaking of the twelve sense bases is due to the fact that when one contemplates their single nature and non-single nature, one is unable to take them as objects. Therefore, it is definitely known that the meaning is not as stated.

Therefore, in the present discussion, it is tried: The place where color, sound, etc. should arise, each according to its own nature, produces the appearance of consciousness. The characteristics of color, etc. are the objects of consciousness. Color consciousness is called color, sound consciousness is called sound, and the rest are all the same.
This color, sound, etc. should be without parts, with a single substance, like colored parts.
Therefore, it has no partless nature in its own dependent place.

However, this color, etc. is an existent thing, with a substance that is obstructive, and can be divided, because of its many natures in the same category, and because it can produce consciousness, etc. in different places. The meaning of atoms is omitted here.
By the power of quantity, existence and non-existence are determined.
Among the various means of valid cognition, direct perception is the most important. If there is no external object, how can it give rise to such a state of awareness?

Among the various means of valid cognition, direct perception is the most important. If there is no external object, how can one give rise to the cognition that this matter is known by my separate sense faculty?
Separate sense faculties are like in dreams and so forth. Although there are no external objects, they can still occur.
This has already been carefully distinguished above.
If this is the case later when the object is perceived, the seen object has already disappeared. How can it be considered direct perception?
Among the various means of valid cognition, if at that time the cognition of direct perception arises, this is known by my separate sense faculty.
At that time, there is nothing seen in the object. It is only determined by mental consciousness, because visual consciousness has already ceased at that time.
Since the meaning is like this, how can that object be considered direct perception?

Moreover, for those who hold different theories, it is accepted that all dharmas do not abide for a moment. When this cognition arises, form and other objects have also already ceased. How can the principle of direct perception be established?
Although he has already explained it well in the above, he still cannot fathom this profound Dharma meaning and raises further objections, saying:
Because of the power of valid cognition, one determines that it exists, or Because it contradicts inferential cognition, one negates it and makes it non-existent in form and other [realms].

Even if one truly determines existence and non-existence through valid cognition, among the various valid cognitions such as inferential cognition and correct teachings, the sense faculties are supreme, because they directly perceive objects and are the nature of results.
Only after there is no contradiction in this [realm of the sense faculties] can one establish it through other valid cognitions.
Since the sense faculties have already directly perceived and cognized form and other [realms], how can they contradict inferential cognition?
How can one rashly negate the existence of form and other [realms]?
How are external forms the objects of the sense faculties?
Because if there are no objects, one cannot give rise to such a cognition in this [realm of the sense faculties], thinking This matter is known by my sense faculties.

The meaning of this statement is that each separate self-realization experiences the arising of characteristics, and then gives rise to a subsequent mind that takes them as objects and expresses them, just as one has previously experienced suffering, pleasure, defilement, etc.
This is certainly not so, as it is the same for other [consciousnesses].
The difference in faculties is like in dreams, etc., as I have already explained in detail.
In the states of dreams, etc., there are also directly perceived objects such as forms, etc., just as you have stated.
The phrase because the mind that reflects on them exists shows that the reason given by the opponent is indeterminate.
However, because of being damaged by dreams, cataracts, and sinful and rebellious thoughts, it is as if one clearly sees with different faculties.
Although there are no real objects, there is the matter of seeing, and it does not go beyond the essence of consciousness.
It is because of directly receiving and accepting the matter that is experienced, in order to cut it off.

By this principle, if one wishes to establish that objects such as forms are separate from consciousness, there is a contradiction, and one is merely stubbornly attached to one's own mind. This also has the fault of the reason being unestablished.
When the subsequent cognition cognizes at a later time, the perceived object has already ceased. How can it be considered a direct perception?

When the eye consciousness and other consciousnesses see forms and other objects, they are actually unable to make this discrimination. This is only because each has its own internal evidence of the nature of the image part.
Based on this as the forerunner, the subsequent mental consciousness takes its definite characteristics, combines them, and is then able to make a definite judgment.
Moreover, at that time the consciousnesses do not arise together.
Even if so, when the forms and other objects and the eye consciousness and other consciousnesses cease, how can they be seen later?
The ability to see does not exist, so how can the discernment be accomplished?
What is hoped for at this very moment?
How can there be seeing from the ceased consciousness?
Moreover, forms and other objects are extinguished together with the consciousness.
Therefore, one should know that this [mental consciousness] is unable to see forms and other objects.
Relying on the power of that seeing, the mind of careful examination observes forms and other objects. How can it be considered to have the nature of a separate root [consciousness] perception?
Moreover, at that time, mental consciousness is cut off and is not commonly accepted as having the nature of direct perception, because it lacks the ability to see and because it has already ceased.
Other masters say:
At the very beginning, it experiences the object, not being tainted by the defilements of discrimination, therefore it definitely takes external form as its real object.
This is also unreasonable, because it is not established.

Because others do not accept external objects such as form apart from verbal expression as what is cognized by consciousness, but because there is an internal self-realization, at that time, without giving rise to speculation, one takes the various aspects of objects as one's object.

They only accept that there is such an internal object, and this also follows its appearance when present, but it is only based on consciousness, just like the commonly accepted suffering, pleasure, defilements, etc.

However, taking those external objects such as form as a separate means of knowledge, this is only a false conceptual attachment, just like this and that number, action, etc., using this difficulty to expand the remaining doubts.
Although there is no object at the time of the dream, there is still the knowledge of the mind.

The same is true of direct perception. For this reason, the subsequent conceptual cognition is not non-existent. They also do not deny the existence of the sense faculties and their objects, which are cognized by the mind and mental factors. It is accepted that there is direct perception that is not separate from self-awareness.
However, regarding external objects, the superimposition of direct perception is to be refuted.
As previously stated, in order to point out the fault of incompleteness, if one does not understand the meaning, one's words will be empty and without substance.
They do not accept the existence of external forms and so on, yet they still rely on them to clarify the existence of direct perception.
However, what they establish is unable to avoid the faults that are to be refuted, therefore,

if the conceptual cognition has never experienced the previous object, it will not be able to generate recollection. It must definitely be accepted that it has previously experienced the external object.
Therefore, it is not established that one can only remember an object that has been previously experienced.
Why is this?
Because there is a reason.

As for the statement the cognition that is like the appearance, even without an external object, the cognition appears as if it were the object, and the eye and other cognitions arise, as explained above.
Next, as for the statement how does memory arise from this? after this cognition, the memory-associated mental consciousness arises with regard to this same appearance.
Therefore, the meaning is not established that memory arises only from experiencing the object.
If that is so, then in the case of form and other objects, one definitely cognizes the appearance through direct perception, and memory arises based on that, just like pleasure and so forth.

One places the image on the memory and grasps it, decisively determining the previous appearance within one's own self-awareness. It is not that one does not experience it, just as in the case of stone and other [insentient objects].
When consciousness of fire, etc. arises, it also cannot produce this memory.
Therefore, by the power of inference, one should definitely have direct perception of form, etc.
If it were otherwise, the accepted memory would become nonexistent.
Moreover, because the object of this feeling is direct perception, worldly discourse calls it seeing.
If form, etc. were of the nature of memory, as commonly accepted, there could be this fault.
But it is not accepted that memory is of external form, etc., because there is reason.
Just as there can be seeing apart from the object, so too is memory, because it is not commonly accepted as the probandum.
The thesis and example have no power to make others understand the feeling of the object.
